ADAM DAVY'S FIVE DREAMS ABOUT EDWARD II. To oure lorde Iesu crist in heuene, Ich to-day shewe myne sweuene, þat ich mette in one ni?th, Of a kni?th of mychel mi?th: His name is ihote sir Edward þe kyng, Prince of Wales, Engelonde þe faire þing. Me mette þat he was armed wel, Boþe wiþ yrne & wiþ stel; And on his helme þat was of stel, A Coroune of gold bicom hym wel. Bifore the shryne of seint Edward he stood, Myd glad chere, & mylde of mood, Mid two kni?ttes armed on eiþer side, þat he ne mi?th þennes goo ne ride. hetilich hij leiden hym vpon, Als hij mi?tten myd swerd don. He stood þere wel swiþe stille, And þoled al-to-gedres her wille; No strook ne ?af he a?einward To þilk þat hym weren wiþerward. Wounde ne was þere blody non, Of al þat hym þere was don. After þat me þou?th, onon, As þe tweie kni?ttes weren gon, In eiþer ere of oure kyng þere spronge out a wel fare þing: Hij wexen out so bri?th so glem þat shyneþ of þe sonne-bem; Of diuers coloures hij weren, þat comen out of boþe his eren ffoure bendes alle by rewe on eiþer ere, Of diuers colours, red & white als hij were; Als fer as me þou[?th] ich mi?th see, hij spredden fer & wyde in þe cuntre. fforsoþe me mette þis ilk sweuene— Ich take to witnesse god of heuene— þe wedenysday bifore þe decollacioun of seint Ion, It is more þan twelue moneþ gon. God me graunte so heuene blis, As me mette þis sweuene as it is. Now god þat is heuene kyng, To mychel ioye tourne þis metyng! Anoþer sweuene me mette, on a tiwes-ni?th Bifore the fest of alle halewen, of þat ilk kni?th; His name is nempned here-bifore; Blissed be þe tyme þat he was bore! ffor we shullen þe day see, Emperour ychosen he worþe of cristiente. God vs graunte þat ilk bone, þat þilk tydyng here we sone Of sir Edward oure derworþ kyng Ich mette of hym anoþere fair metyng: To oure lorde of heuene ich telle þis, þat my sweuene tourne to mychel blis. Me þou?th he rood vpon an Asse— And þat ich take god to witnesse!— ywonden he was in a Mantel gray; Toward Rome he nom his way; Vpon his heuede sat an gray hure; It semed hym wel a mesure; he rood wiþouten hose & sho,— his wone was nou?th so forto do;— his shankes semeden al blood rede; Myne herte wop for grete drede; Als a pilgryme he rood to Rome, And þider he com wel swiþe sone. Þe þrid sweuene me mette a ni?th, Ri?th of þat derworþe kni?th; þe wedenysday a ni?th it was, Next þe day of seint lucie bifore cristenmesse. Ich shewe þis, god of heuene: To mychel ioye he tourne my sweuene! Me þou?th þat ich was at Rome, And þider ich com swiþe sone: þe Pope, & sir Edward oure kyng, Boþe hij hadden a newe dubbyng; Hure gray was her cloþing; Of oþere cloþes sei? ich noþing. þe pope ?ede bifore, mytred wel faire I-wys; þe kyng Edward com corouned myd gret blis; þat bitokneþ he shal be Emperour in cristianete: Iesus crist ful of grace, Graunte oure kyng, in euery place, Maistrie of his wiþerwynes, And of alle wicked sarasynes! Me met a sweuene, on worþing-ni?th. Of þat ilche derworþe kni?th; God ich it shewe, & to witnesse take, And so shilde me fro synne & sake! In-to an chapel ich com of oure lefdy; Iesus crist, hire leue son, stood by; On rode he was, an louelich Man, Als þilk þat on rode was don. He vnneiled his honden two, And seide, ‘wiþ þe kni?th he wolde go’: “Maiden, & moder, & mylde quene, Ich mote my kni?th to-day sene. Leue moder, ?iue me leue, ffor ich ne may no lenger bileue; Ich mote conueye þat ilk kni?th, þat vs haþ serued day and ni?th: In pilerinage he wil gon, To bien awreke of oure fon.” “Leue son, ?oure wille, so mote it be, for þe kni?th boþe day & ni?th haþ serued me, Boþe at oure wille wel faire I-wys, þerfore he haþ serued heuene-riche blis.” God þat is in heuene so bri?th, Be wiþ oure kyng boþe day & ni?th! Amen, Amen, so mote it be! þerto biddeþ a pater noster & an Aue. Adam, þe marchal, of stretford-atte-bowe— Wel swiþe wide his name is yknowe,— He hym-self mette þis metyng— To witnesse he takeþ Iesu heuene kyng,— On Wedenysday in clene leinte A voice me bede I ne shulde nou?th feinte; Of þe sweuenes þat her ben write, I shulde swiþe don my lorde kyng to wite. Ich ansuerde, ‘þat I ne mi?th for derk gon.’ þe vois me bad goo, for li?th ne shuld ich faile non, And þat I ne shulde lette for noþing, þat ich shulde shewe þe kyng my metyng. fforþ ich went swiþe onon, Estward as me þou?th ich mi?th gon: þe li?th of heuene me com to, As ich in my waye shulde go. “Lorde, my body ich ?elde þee to, What ?oure wille is wiþ me to do. Ich take to witnesse god of heuene, þat soþlich ich mette þis ilche sweuene! I ne reiche what ?ee myd my body do, Als wisselich Iesus of heuene my soule vndergo.” Þe þursday next þe beryng of oure lefdy, Me þou?th an Aungel com sir Edward by: þe Aungel bitook sir Edward on honde; Al bledyng þe foure forþer clawes so were of þe lombe. At Caunterbiry, bifore þe hei?e autere, þe kyng stood, ycloþed al in rede: murre he was of þat blee red as blood. God, þat was on gode-friday don on þe rode, So turne my sweuene ni?th & day to mychel gode! Tweye poynt? þere ben þat ben vnshewed, ffor me ne worþe to clerk ne lewed; Bot to sir Edward oure kyng, hym wil ich shewe þilk metyng. Ich telle ?ou forsoþe wiþouten les, Als god of heuene maide marie to moder ches, þe Aungel com to me, Adam Dauy, & sede, “Bot þou, Adam, shewe þis, þee worþe wel yuel mede!” þerfore, my lorde sir Edward þe kyng, I shewe ?ou þis ilk metyng, As þe Aungel it shewed me in a visioun. Bot þis tokenyng bifalle, so dooþ me in-to prisoun! Lorde, my body is to ?oure wille; þei? ?ee willeþ me þerfore spille, Ich it wil take in þolemodenesse, Als god graunte vs heuene blisse; And lete vs neuere þerof mysse, þat we ne moten þider wende in clennesse! Amen, amen, so mote it be, And lete vs neuere to oþere waye tee! Who so wil speke myd me, Adam þe marchal, In stretforþe-bowe he is yknowe, & ouere al. Ich ne shewe nou?th þis forto haue mede, Bot for god almi?tties drede; ffor it is sooþ.
